s.text: For someone writing on desire, Wolf, curiously, has a good deal of trouble describing the actual experience of letting loose.
"As adult women, those of us who are heterosexual sometimes have a sense of a lost Eden," she writes at one point.
There's a kind of intellectual greed going on here, almost a sense of entitlement.
It can refer to a purely physical arousal, or to a heartfelt experience of love.
It can also refer to a more idle, juvenile form of daydreaming--to the heated but generic longing a pop star evokes, for instance, when he wails, "I want you."
In the passage that follows, she recalls the summer she was 13, living on a kibbutz, dying to sneak off and make out with a forbidden Irish boy named Devin.
And in the next chapter we're asked to take it as an established fact that all women, everywhere, since the beginning of time, have lived in fear of entering "The Slut's Dominion."
The sky isn't always sunny: Wolf gets groped by a menacing stranger, and a jealous boyfriend hits her.
As a critic Wolf usually hits the target, or at least gets near it.
I couldn't help imagining a life-size dancing mascot.
I suppose it's only fair that girls win equal rights to good old, solipsistic Desire No.
